that's one of the reasons why more recently in in version 9 which came last
September we introduced a module system which provides a facility for encapsulating internal implementation

so Java 9 came out last September there's a long long long list of

you can go and look at them you can read all of the text of you know who was proposed by what did they say what problem are they trying to solve what

this you'll see there there are kind of a number of things we did one was introducing a module system the second one was using it to modularize the jdk
itself and you can see over to the right a small section of a diagram of the
module graph that exists for the JDK class library right and then you can you
can see a neat thing here if your application depends so your company application is up there in in green and
it's depending on a couple of modules but those modules in turn are depending on a few other modules well before it
was very hard to figure out what your dependencies were now with the module system it's it's very very easy for you
to find out exactly what you're inadvertently depending on and also what
you're not depending on and the reason that's interesting is because what you now can do is create your own runtime
that has your application and the parts of the JDK and only the parts of the JDK
that your application needs so that's kind of cool right
that makes things smaller of course you know but even more importantly it can
make things more secure and the reason it makes things more secure is things
that may have been you know vulnerabilities that may have existed in some of those other modules that were that you weren't using but we're
carrying around might have been able to be exploited and now they're not there so they can't be you've effectively kind
of reduced your security surface and contained it to just the things that
that your application needs it also allows us to do things like you know smarter ways of detecting
when somebody is calling across boundaries that they shouldn't by basically being able to see when someone
is reaching inside another module I won't go into how this was done before you know there's been a story for this
for years but trust me when I say that the way it's done with modules is just inherently more secure it also makes
things easier for compatibility for upgrades and what I mean by that is
again you now know if your application is reaching in and using something that's not guaranteed not to change
right so you know you may be ok with that but at least you know if it changes
you're not going to be surprised because you kind of knew that yeah I knew I was using that thing I shouldn't event not ok and and so it's easier for you to

think you know that that helps us all all move more quickly and it's one of the reasons why frankly we feel that now
after 9 was the time to move to six-month releases and not before that because we think after you know when
we're all living in a modular world it will be far easier for people to to update more rapidly ok another one of
the things in 9 and future there's some work on ahead of time compilation so
this basically is now that we know which modules you're going to use it's actually possible to add an installation
step where now we know what hardware and operating system you're running on it's possible to actually do some ahead of
time compilation so that a startup is faster because typically for the JVM or
a java application the first thing the JVM does is starts up and then it starts to load your application and that
results in a whole lot of class loading going on and then those classes are initially interpreted and then over time
they're compiled once you know once it figures out what the hot paths are and
that whole process both from startup and then warm up to running it kind of full optimized capacity can actually take
quite a while and so what ahead of time compilation does is it allows you to analyze one of
these startups or a group of startups and figure out what's the end state I'd like to get to and then sort of you know
essentially dump the contents of that so the next time you start up all it has to do is memory map that and boom you're
running at full speed so that's pretty cool we've really just kind of scratched
a surface on this there's been a lot of work done not not only by Oracle in an open chat ek but kind of across the
industry on this over the years and I expect we're gonna see a lot of work on this especially for workloads that are
fairly small but you want to have come up quickly so if you think of something like micro services where you basically
want something to come up quickly do something then go away this is the kind of technology you want rather than the
sort of traditional legacy Java technology which was really about ok it's fine that it takes half an hour for
